3.47.text:
We might be a nation of bargain hunters. But
we don't shirk when it comes to game shooting.

9.12.text:
One of the most expensive, extravagant, exciting
shooting experiences is glorious grouse on

15.52.text:
the glorious 12th and to mark it the boys
from Browning are stepping out in style. They

23.50.text:
are going to show off their guns, they are
going to be gunning the engines of some superb

27.84.text:
modern shooting brakes - and you are going
to walk away from this film with expert tips

37.76.text:
In preparation for some shooting later in
the season they're taking three versions of

41.38.text:
their top end B25s out for the day of simulated
grouse. First they're stopping off at an appropriate

48.22.text:
pile in the country for some refreshments
and to let the cars 12-cylinder engines cool.

53.49.text: 12! - I see a theme developing here.

56.82.text:
What better way to celebrate the start of
the grouse season, or the game season in the

61.18.text:
UK, the glorious 12th by incorporating some
beautiful guns in the B25, fantastic game

66.39.text:
guns. Some beautiful cars, the Astin Martins
and the Bentleys, all 12 cylinder of course

71.31.text:
bringing that combination of the glorious
12th and glorious 12 cylinders together and

75.89.text:
a beautiful location here at Brocket Hall
today. And start of the season on the 12th

80.02.text: August, it all comes together very nicely.

81.67.text:
The cars are on loan from HR Owen in Cheltenham.
At this point we'd be asking Dom to help us

88.52.text:
out with the facts and figures of these British
beasts, but he's not coming until later, instead

93.77.text:
we have Bentley brand manager Paul Carvell
on hand.

97.36.text:
This is the Bentley GT speed, W12 engine 616
break horse power. Fastest road going saloon

106.12.text:
that Bentley have produced to date at 205
miles per hour. Next we have got the Astin

112.67.text:
Martin V12 Vantage roadster. Underneath that
bonnet they have squeezed the V12 6 litre

118.83.text:
510 break horse power engine into the car.
Top speed of 190 miles per hour. 0 - 60 in

125.87.text:
4.1 seconds. GTC speed again will catapault
you from 0 - 60 in 4.5 seconds, but all of

132.21.text:
the comfort and luxury of a Bentley. The Astin
Martin Vanquish Flightship of our range 565

139.58.text:
break horse power V12 engine all carbon ... pretty
stunning car with ... engine. Get a mental

148.64.text:
orgasm!!!!If the cars don't do it for you
the guns will - but more about them in a minute...

154.13.text:
Our backdrop of Brocket Hall has an infamous
connection with exotic motors. It hit the

158.85.text:
press in the 1990s when Lord Brocket was jailed
for burying supercars in the grounds of the

163.89.text:
house and claiming on the insurance - but
those were Italian cars, so his actions are

168.46.text:
entirely understandable. Today it's an exclusive
golf club and venue.

173.29.text:
It was originally built in 1760. Obviously
owned by the Brocket family which is quite

178.86.text:
a well known story I am sure. Our company
took it over in the early 90's and built it

185.20.text:
up to what it is now two championship golf
courses. The award winning restaurant over

190.96.text:
there as well and the hall over here as an
exclusive use venue.

195.24.text:
Right that's enough pre-grouse moor posing
- we need to make sure these guns are able

199.16.text:
to strut their stuff when it matters. So we're
off to Atkin Grant and Lang shooting school

204.12.text:
just a few miles away. They've been busy here
developing a special stand for anyone wanting

209.53.text:
to experience the next best thing to a driven
day .. they also offer sartorial advice, Dom.

216.08.text:
So this isn't your typical stand at your average
clay ground. So can you talk us through the

221.46.text: set up you have got here.

222.48.text:
Yes, what we have got here we have actually
got stone from Yorkshire. We have had this

226.37.text:
shipped down for us. We have got heather here
which you will find on a grouse moor. As you

230.74.text:
can see it is sunk into the ground so as we
look out we can't see any traps or anything

235.25.text:
in front of us. It is very similar to when
you are grouse shooting you have got low horizon.

238.66.text:
We have got six traps out here so they will
just appear. And we have also got traps you

243.05.text:
can move around so you can just shoot them
over each shoulder.

245.93.text:
So this really is as close as you are going
to get to the real thing.

249.51.text:
Absolutely. Yes absolutely and we do spend
a lot of time setting up the targets so that

253.41.text:
they are actually coming down hill into the
butt instead of a lot of clay targets will

257.64.text: go up over you like a partridge target.

259.14.text:
I have done a bit of shotgun shooting Charlie
but clearly I am a peasant and driven grouse

264.63.text:
is not something normally open to an amateur
like myself. So could you give me a few tips

268.63.text: on what I should be doing.

269.66.text:
Yes, absolutely. So when you are actually
shooting grouse they are coming a lot faster

273.33.text:
and a lot flatter than pheasants and partridges.
So instead of a pheasant being nice and high

277.60.text:
you are going to give it a long lead in front.
These grouse are coming very flat and you

281.07.text:
have got to get out there at them. So a target
when it is coming in towards you, a lot of

285.85.text:
the time you can still see the bird over the
top of the gun because the gun is pointing

289.07.text: up into the direction where it is going.

291.15.text:
Ok so there is not a great deal of lead. But
you have to be quite positive with your lead.

296.64.text:
Yes, absolutely so it is really important
to get the line of the bird so if the bird

300.00.text:
is quartering in towards you, if he is coming
in towards you and just fairs off to the side

305.17.text:
just go onto the wing tip in the direction
it is going.

309.19.text:
Let's hear a little more about the guns on
show today. Each of our three Browning guys

313.89.text:
has a different model, but all of them have
been hand crafted by the gunmakers and engravers

318.36.text:
at the Browning Custom shop in Liege, in Belgium.
We start at the top and the pair of B25 D5Gs

324.26.text:
in 20-gauge on loan from Reeves at the Royal
Berkshire Shooting School.

328.64.text:
I mean this is the top of the market gun.
Obviously it is £66,000 for a pair it is

333.15.text:
not something you buy lightly.Thankfully there
is a lot of money still around and people

337.96.text:
do like to buy the best. We are in the market
of supplying probably the finest game gun

342.85.text:
in the world, certainly for balance and feel
and we do have a number of people requesting

349.53.text:
guns like this on a weekly basis and that
is why we have a 24 month lead time.

354.31.text:
Next is the 28 gauge B25 on loan from Ian
Coley Shooting Ground and it suits Andy down

360.17.text:
It is one of the few guns in life which is
both aesthetically pleasing to the eye and

365.83.text:
is also more reliable than most and is hard
working. If you go to any gun shop in the

370.52.text:
country you will find B25's that have been
around from the 50's and 60's, plenty from

375.94.text:
the 70's and they are still working and going
strong today. There are very few guns or models

381.48.text:
that you will find that have been going that
long and that well.

385.58.text:
Lastly it's the biggest Browning with the
biggest Browning team member, Allister.

390.43.text:
Starts from around £22,000. This one actually
comes with a few extras. Such as the round

397.55.text:
pistol grip here and this one is my personal
favourite because it is the 12 bore calibre

401.09.text:
and obviously being the biggest chap out of
the three it brings down the biggest birds.

405.34.text:
But it is a beautiful weapon. Great investment,
great value for money and it is around half

409.74.text:
the price of a D grade side plated gun. So
value for money it is superb.

415.75.text:
They say money doesn't bring you happiness
- but it certainly gives you choice. It could

420.19.text:
mean deciding between a Aston or a Bentley
or if they don't raise the hairs on the back

424.79.text:
of your neck, a pair of B25s just might espcecially
when the birds are coming at you like little

430.50.text:
If you want anymore information about the
custom shop and these B25s email info@isbrands.com

436.86.text: or watch our Browning Factory film.
